Award.AwardTitle: Pre and post molt biology of emperor penguins - Oden trans - Ross / Amundsen Sea cruise
Award.AbstractNarration: The emperor penguin dives deeper and longer, fasts longer, and endures the harshest weather conditions of all diving birds. It spends about four and half months per annum deep in Antarctic pack ice away from shore and stations, and thus is largely unavailable for study. This time includes preparation for the molt, and travel to the colony to breed, a time period in which great swings in body weight occur. This study will fill an important gap in what we know about the biology of the annual cycle of the emperor by examining the molt-post molt period. The P.I. proposes to traverse the Amundsen and Bellingshausen seas on the Oden, to locate and tag emperor penguins during the molt season. The objectives are to (1) Place satellite tags on 20 adult post molt birds to determine their route, rate of travel, and diving behavior as they return back to their breeding colonies, (2) Obtain an index of body condition, (3) Collect guano to determine the type of food consumed by emperor penguins in the region, (4) Conduct shipboard surveys to sight and plot the location and abundance of adult and juvenile birds on the ship's track. The PI hypothesizes that bird dives will be shallow during the initial post-molt phase, and that food will consist primarily of krill; that there will be differential dispersal of birds from the Ross Sea vs. Marie Byrd Land, with Ross Sea birds traveling farther; and that the greatest adult mortality occurs during the molt and early post molt period. Broader impacts include training of a post doc, a graduate student, and an aquarium volunteer. The P.I. also will present findings through a website, through public lectures, and in collaboration with the Birch aquarium.

The emperor penguin is one of the most recognized animal icons in the world. Many are aware pf the colony side of their life history from October through December (spring and summer). Many descriptions in different media from books, journal reports and numerous video documentaries are available. These are the times of long days when the sun is above the horizon for up to three months, and the weather is relatively warm. Most of the studies come from Pointe Géologie, a colony that is just a short walking distance from the French base of Dumont d' Urville, but a long distance from the ice edge. The walk is worthwhile because colonies are on annual fast ice, which remain solid until the chicks fledge in early summer. When the chicks are mature both they and the adults depart on long journeys. The chicks travel north beyond  the southern ocean, and  little is known of their activities for the next three to four years. The adults remain near the continent, but travel extensively until the next breeding season in April. The first part of the adult journey is to cross the Ross Sea and molt in the eastern Ross Sea and shed their feathers on thick, multi-year pack ice. The birds molt their entire coat over the course of 35 days. This process is energetically demanding, and by the end of the process, a bird loses half its body weight. They are famished from the fast, weak from the muscle loss, and are facing the onset of winter with the need to fatten over the next 2.5 months if they are to breed in April

There are two distinct populations of emperor penguins. Those found around the northern perimeter of the continent at latitudes that range from 62-67o S. They deal with a different light regime from those of the Ross Sea. The genetically distinct Ross Sea emperor penguins have colonies ranging from Cape Roget (72o S) to Cape Crozier (78o S). During the winter this latitudinal difference has a strong effect on weather and light conditions. It is colder in the south, but more important, it is darker. From the end of April until early August it is dark. For a visual hunter this puts constraints on their winter journey and feeding behavior. If the climate continues to warm around Antarctica, and the continental fast ice decays earlier, many of the northern colonies may become untenable and the residents will be forced to move further south. Such a possibility increases the interest in the travels of emperor penguins during the non-breeding time of their annual cycle, and especially through the winter night endured the southern birds.

The major obstacle for studying their habits during the autumn and winter is that they do not dwell at the colonies, or for all we know, at any fixed location for any length of time. Instead, they travel through some of the most remote places this side of the moon. With no supportive fixed research bases to help out, and dealing with emperor penguins in locations of uncertain ice distribution, we needed a special approach to determine the habitat preferences and foraging behavior of this habitual ice dweller. Our endeavor required the capabilities of the Icebreaker Nathaniel B. Palmer from 2 February to 2 April 2013. With a team of four our goal was to tag birds soon after their molt with satellite transmitters equipped with up-to-date technology. We hoped the tracking extend well into the winter. Our project was one of the first tests of transmitter duration in such harsh conditions. Twenty-one transmitters were attached to birds from near the Drygalski Ice Tongue in the western Ross Sea to Cape Colbeck at the eastern edge of the Ross Sea in the month of March. From the transmitted data we found that all birds in the southeast preferred to forage in the vicinity of the Bay of Whales from March to early May.
